Comment: Among the key sticking point of the negotiations was the question of security guarantees – and whether the US would provide them as part of the deal. *Trump initially refused that, saying he wants Ukraine to sign the agreement first and talk about guarantees later*.  That was good for a laugh.  And I suspect Ukraine got the better part of this deal (they have better negotiators).  maga was just desperate to announce that some sort of deal had been signed.

Comment: And walking away after that statement was, and will always be, the right choice. In negotiations you hammer out every single detail before signing anything, leaving absolutely no ambiguity between the parties as what will follow. Had Ukraine signed then, they would have zero security guarantees offered ever, and full obligation to the mineral agreements that they made, all while Russia pounds their backsides.
Author: KeviRun

Comment: That's really what this is.  It's a non-committal talking point killer for Ukraine with a small potential of upside. Costs them nothing, ends the 'he won't deal' non-sense.   I'm surprised the Whitehouse went for it as there's nothing here unless the administration actually wants to work with Ukraine.  Trump gets his win now, but he upped the costs of siding with Putin. There are still countries (and markets) holding on to a hope of a US course correction; it'll be the end of that hope if he betrays Ukraine.

Comment: Good points.  Trump believes with all his heart that he is genius negotiator.  In fact, he is a terrible business man and negotiator who could not even make a go of a casino, which is the closest thing to a license to print money you can get.  Nevertheless, Trump is convinced that his legacy lies in ”winning” negotiations favorable to the US.  The point of tariffs, for Trump, is to coerce concessions from as many countries as possible.  Ukraine looks like an easy mark even without tariffs because it is in an existential fight for its existence.  Trump thinks he is a savvy negotiator because he wants to exploit Ukraine’s tragedy.   The reality is that Trump is not merely a monster, he is also an imbecile.  He wants to use tariffs to extort concessions, but all he has accomplished is killing the goose that laid the golden egg for American prosperity.  Trump is a wrecking ball destroying America, and this is not sustainable.  I don’t see how he lasts a year in office.
Author: Beantown-Jack

Comment: As it stands, this deal is really more about tariffs than resources.  The fact is that Trump has given Ukraine all the cards it needs with his tariffs. Look at the line that Ukraine and the US will have no tariffs under this deal.  In the long run, that means the US will be able to buy raw materials from Ukraine without tariffs, so raw materials from Ukraine will be cheaper for Americans.  But in the short run, what's actually more important now is the fact that Ukraine produces food.  And zero tariffs mean that Ukrainian food will be cheaper for the US than anyone else's.  For Ukraine, getting into the US market only means that without tariffs, it will still earn more than with tariffs.   And for Trump, this means finally lowering prices on something (if, of course, he thinks of stopping trading companies from raising prices even on tariff-free products, because for corporations, the absence of tariffs will mean that they can squeeze out more profit (on the other hand, Ukraine is actually interested in its goods being cheaper on a potential new market, which means that Ukrainian special services will begin to interfere with American corporations).

Comment: You brush past the fact that no one; the US included; demanded repayment.  Ever.  90% of what Ukraine got were weapons unused or in garden sheds.  HIMARS?  It was believed to be ineffective.  Most countries had them in sheds.  Only 10% of the donations were new builds.  And I am in a country that supplied >200 new vehicle builds.  A lot of what Ukraine got was considered out of date.  Why should they pay?  They owe nothing.    Back to your original question: why are potential former allies defending the US?  Ever again?  We did once, and they made clear how they feel about any/all of us.  Straight talk: 9/11 the US was lucky to have Canada.  According to US NORTHCOM general, they still are!  But, they want to replay Russia's invasion on Canada.  They want to take Greenland from Denmark.  They have resoundingly proven unreliable to every ally they ever had.  After we all lived and some died defending them.    Once bitten.  Twice shy.

Comment: And the signed version of the deal literally does not have a clause on debts. The only debts that are possible under it are only in relation to future arms deliveries. At the same time, the US is obliged to help Ukraine attract investments, and any infrastructure and profits from the fund must be spent in Ukraine. Frankly speaking, it really looks like after the fiasco with the Tariffs, Trump is ready to sign anything just to be able to show the signed agreement to voters. Hmm, against this background, I am not even surprised that the American media do not write about what points are in the new agreement, while any references to the agreement itself are redirected to previous versions of the agreement and not to what is written. In fact, Trump is again lying that he persuaded Ukraine when it turned out the opposite.
